Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Building an Intelligent, Uncertainty-Resilient Detection and Tracking Sensor Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Detection, identification, and tracking of CBRNE (Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, and Explosive) plumes can be accomplished by combining the modalities of sensor and cyber networks. The sensor network provides information about physical-space activities, e.g., locations and movements of the plume sources. The cyber network provides storage and computational resources to analyze and infer where the plume originated, the trajectory of its movement, and the prediction of its future movement. The challenges in realizing such a sensor cyber network include intelligent sensing (intelligent sensor selection and coverage) and the capability to deal with uncertainties (uncertainty in measurement as well as in modeling). This project proposes to leverage the convergence between the sensor and the cyber networks to achieve these goals. In particular, the plan is to carry out three synergistic research tasks: 1) network formation by sensor selection, placement, and coverage; 2) sensor tasking protocol with temporal/spatial uncertainty management; 3) protocols for reliable sensor-cyber communication supporting the above two tasks. The PIs will prototype the research results and integrate the prototypes for different components to build the sensor cyber network for plume detection, identification and tracking. They will also evaluate the sensor cyber network using various test scenarios in collaboration with Oak Ridge National Lab. If successful, the project will provide technology for building detection and tracking sensor networks that can give great protection to people and the environment against harmful plumes.

This project aims to manage uncertainty and achieve resilient sensing
results at low cost and with acceptable manual effort. To do so, we
incorporated optimization and machine learning techniques to infer key
information necessary for robust decision making under faults and
attacks. As one of our applications, we consider the emerging area of
green building energy management because it is a timely topic given
worldwide concerns on the sustainability of urban systems.

We highlight below a few of the most significant results from this
project:

    Supero: We designed, implemented, and evaluated a novel
    residential power usage monitoring system for appliances that emit
    physical signals, such as light or sound. Our approach leverages
    indirect sensors to disaggregate the total power consumption
    measured by a smart meter, without prior training regarding the
    consumption patterns of appliances. Extensive evaluation in five
    real homes shows that our system estimates the energy consumption
    of individual appliances with less than 7.5% error. Moreover,
    non-professional users can quickly deploy our system with
    considerable flexibility.

    Harmonic-Sense: We created a power usage disaggregation system
    that selectively uses high-frequency current waveform signatures
    from an add-on battery-powered mote hosting a current transducer
    (CT) sensor to complement low-frequency data from an
    infrastructure power meter. The system supports flexible
    deployment scenarios, including the decoupling of voltage and
    current channels. In a proof-of-concept testbed with five common
    household appliances, our system shows less than 8% error in
    estimating per-load energy consumption, making its accuracy
    comparable to that of competing methods, which provide less
    fine-grained information and/or are likely to be more expensive to
    install.

    Solutions of Markov games: We showed that an approach of lazy
    evaluation can allow the defender to focus on the present most
    relevant game states, which we call the interesting
    states. Furthermore, if a game state, say S, has insignificant
    impact (as determined by a tunable threshold parameter) on an
    interesting state, say T, because either S is far from T in time
    or because the discount factor of future rewards is high, we
    showed that S, as well as an entire subgraph reachable through S,
    can be pruned with little impact when computing the
    solution. Lastly, we found that by suitably structuring component
    steps in the solution, we can decouple some of the steps and
    expose parallelism in the computation. Our numerical results
    showed that when these techniques were used together, we could
    reduce the solution time by more than 90% with practically no loss
    of accuracy for an IEEE 14-bus system.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims to manage uncertainty and achieve resilient sensing results at low cost and with acceptable manual effort. To do so, we incorporated optimization and machine learning techniques to infer key information necessary for robust decision making under faults and attacks. As one of our applications, we consider the emerging area of green building energy management because it is a timely topic given worldwide concerns on the sustainability of urban systems. We highlight below a few of the most significant results from this project: Supero: We designed, implemented, and evaluated a novel residential power usage monitoring system for appliances that emit physical signals, such as light or sound. Our approach leverages indirect sensors to disaggregate the total power consumption measured by a smart meter, without prior training regarding the consumption patterns of appliances. Extensive evaluation in five real homes shows that our system estimates the energy consumption of individual appliances with less than 7.5% error. Moreover, non-professional users can quickly deploy our system with considerable flexibility. Harmonic-Sense: We created a power usage disaggregation system that selectively uses high-frequency current waveform signatures from an add-on battery-powered mote hosting a current transducer (CT) sensor to complement low-frequency data from an infrastructure power meter. The system supports flexible deployment scenarios, including the decoupling of voltage and current channels. In a proof-of-concept testbed with five common household appliances, our system shows less than 8% error in estimating per-load energy consumption, making its accuracy comparable to that of competing methods, which provide less fine-grained information and/or are likely to be more expensive to install. Solutions of Markov games: We showed that an approach of lazy evaluation can allow the defender to focus on the present most relevant game states, which we call the interesting states. Furthermore, if a game state, say S, has insignificant impact (as determined by a tunable threshold parameter) on an interesting state, say T, because either S is far from T in time or because the discount factor of future rewards is high, we showed that S, as well as an entire subgraph reachable through S, can be pruned with little impact when computing the solution. Lastly, we found that by suitably structuring component steps in the solution, we can decouple some of the steps and expose parallelism in the computation. Our numerical results showed that when these techniques were used together, we could reduce the solution time by more than 90% with practically no loss of accuracy for an IEEE 14-bus system. The research results were presented in major journals and international conferences in networking and the project trained two graduate students at Purdue University. The project developed a number of robust and efficient algorithms for sensor networks and for smart green buildings. The algorithms use low cost sensors and unsupervised learning to simplify deployment efforts, which make them feasible for practical use in end users' homes and offices. We created working prototypes of the sensing systems, and demonstrated them in major international conferences. Our work also introduced novel methods to make wireless sensor networks resilient to faults and attacks with little energy consumption. Our demonstrated technologies will have impact on reducing the carbon footprints of urban societies, thus contributing to general environmental sustainability efforts. They contributed to a technology base for behavioral social scientists to encourage people to adopt energy-efficient usage of appliances in everyday living. Our techniques also increase the trustworthiness of wireless sensor networks in general. ...
